'Legation, London. 20th November, 1940 My Lord, I have the honour to refer to Your Excellency 1 s note of the 17th October, No. W 10496/4119/27, regarding the K.L.M. service Batavia-Lydda and also concerning inter-allied co-operation for which the K.L.M. might render assistance. As to the paragraphs 1 and 2 of Your Excellency’s above-mentioned note, I have the honour to inform you, that the conditions laid down for the operation of the said service via Bahrein have been submitted to the management of the K.L.M. in the Netherlands Indies. It is hoped that a reply will be received in the near future. In paragraph 3 of your note, Your Excellency enquired to what extent it might be possible for the K.L.M. to render assistance to the joint war effort. In this connexion I have the honour to inform Your ( Excellency that Her Majesty’s Government agree with the thought underlying the proposal that the K.L.M. should, as far as possible, co-operate with the air services of the British Empire in the common interest. They are, 1 therefore, prepared in principle to further the conclusion of an agreement between the Governments of the Netherlands, the United Kingdom and India to that end. Having regard, however, to the limited personnel I and material available, it will be necessary to receive more detailed information as to the extent of co-operation visualised, as the K.L.M. would only then be in a position to consider whether efficient assistance can be rendered. I have been instructed and have the honour to request Your Excellency to inform me of the detailed proposals on the subject. I have, etc., (Sgd).E. Michiels van Verduynen. London, <40 6th September 1940. '\ My Lord, I have the honour to inform Your Excellency that the K.L.M. (Royal Dutch Air Lines) for some time have been operating an Air Service between Batavia and Lydda. The best route is the one via Iran; however, it appears that the Iranian Government still refuses to grant permission to fly across Iranian territory. As a result the K.L.M. now flies via Bahrein, but permission for each separate journey has to be applied for in Simla. Applications put forward in this manner are expensive and cause much inconvenience. Therefore, the Director General for Air at Simla has suggested that application for a permanent permission to fly via Bahrein should be made with His Majesty’s Government in London. I have been instructed and have the honour to request Your Excellency to be good enough to approach the Department concerned with a view to obtaining the abovementioned permission for the K.L.M. Dear Residency, -our express letter No. C/492 of 27th September, 1939, to the Secretary of State for India about the visit of Signor Venturini to Bahrein. It is regretted that the Political Agent at Bahrein did not receive prior warning of the arrival of Signor Venturini in Bahrein. As the Political Agent will now be aware, the Acting Consul informed him in an air mail letter No, 26/7/8 of the 18th September, that he had that day granted a visa to Signor Venturini. It was understood that Signor Venturini intended to spend two or three days in Basra, and he seems in fact to have done so. The Acting Consul therefore saw no special reason to telegraph to the Political Agent. It is evident that the letter did not catch the aeroplane it was intended to catch, owing possibly to delay in the censor’s office, despite the obviously official character of the communication. As regards the general question of granting visas in war-time which the Political Agent, Bahrein, raises in paragraph 2 of his express letter to the Political Resident, it should be noted that, except in the case of visas for the United Kingdom, no fresh instructions modifying the existing regulations have been received as a result of the outbreak of war. This, and the fact that Signor Venturini, although he only applied for the visa in person on 18th September/ The Residency, Persian Gulf, BUSHIRE.<er- September, had been informed of the terms of your approval of his application immediately upon receipt of your telegram No. T 182 of 23rd August, would have made the withdrawal of his facilities very difficult, except on some very solid ground advanced by you; and we note that you did not think, fit to take the initiative in this direction. We would mention too that wehad had instructions to be very careful to avoid any provocation to Italy and to see that the Iraqis conformed with our attitude. In the absence of fresh instructions regarding visas for other parts of the Empire and territories under British control, and having regard to the fact that the applicant was not an enemy alien and that, as indicated in paragraph 4 of the Political Resident’s telegram No. 182 of 23rd August, he was to be kept under observation during his stay in Bahrein, it was not considered that, in the absence of any initiative from you, the approval of the issue of a visa of strictly limited validity to Signor Venturini needed reconsideration in the event of war. In connexion with paragraph 3 of the Political Resident’s letter, the Acting Consul was assured categorically by Messrs. Dwyer and Company, who are the local agent for the Ala Littoria Company, and are a firm under Brit ish management usually considered reliable, that Signor Venturini was only visiting Bahrein in order to appoint a booking agent there, and that there was no question at present of extending the service beyond Basra. Nevertheless, we are not surprised to hear that his Company are thinking of exploiting to their own advantage the situation in which the war has placed the Imperial Airways. The Acting Consul applied to Messrs. Dwyer rather than to Signor Venturini direct because shortly after making his original application for a visa, Signor Venturini left for Haifa and remained there for several days, no doubt in order to ascertain what the attitude/ r) attitude of his country would be as a result of hostilities* ^ i r* i W d y, ^ • \ oKth^ outttreak . o y -.-J ¥e are very sorry to have caused you so much trouble and quite appreciate your anxiety not to have aliens arriving in your midst without due warning. Our policy as regards the use of the Arab Coast, more especially the Trucial Coast, by foreign aircraft was thoroughly reviewed at the time when it was considered necessary to change the route of Imperial Airways from the Persian to the Arab side of the Gulf in 1932. (Reference P.Z.5019/32 for full account of the views then expressed by the interested Departments). Our policy has been governed by three considerations: (l) The difficulty of guaranteeing security in the Trucial Sheikdoms. Our own police measures are on a very small scale, and in our Treaty relations with the Sheiks we -■ttn-ekirtook not to interfere in their internal affairs. On the other hand, were we to secure for foreign air services equal facilities from the Sheiks, we should have to guarantee their security (unless they were to be left to take their own precautions themselves, which we could not allow) . Thus we should assume responsibilities which it would/2 would be difficult to carry out without infringing our agreements with the Sheiks. We must, therefore, keep such facilities that are granted down to a minimum and make it a cardinal point to insist that in so far as facilities are granted, foreign companies o-teould adhere to the advice and instructions of the local British Authorities on both sides of the Gulf*., (forced landings on the Persian side are lUM l»< not impossibleand that their services aro p4gifted- down to routes and landing grounds aeoording to tho pl-a.no of which we ay»- always fully informed in advance. (2) The maintenance of the Maritime Trao-pa. This is largely governed by the foregoing observations, but it is to be borne in mind that too extensive facilities might always be made a pretext by a foreign power for naval penetration of the Gulf. Italy has been specifically referred to in this connection. (3) The need for obtaining reciprocal facilities for our Air Companies from foreign powers (this is more a matter of concern to the Foreign Office than to us). Sir, In your note No. 448 of 23rd March, 1936, you were so good as to inform me that the Royal Dutch Air Lines (K.L.M. ) had approached His Majesty 1 s Consul'* General at Bushire with a view to obtaining permission to fly over Muscat and Bahrain and to use the aerodromes at Gwadur and Muharraq for emergency purposes. As a consequence of this application, permission was granted in due course by the Sheikh of Bahrain for certain American built Douglas, type DC-2 (twin engined), aircraft of the Royal Dutch Air Line, bearing the following Registration Marks: 'PH-AKI PH-AKK PH-AKL PH-AKN PH-AKO PH-AKP PH-AKQ PH-AKS” to land in Muhairaq and to fly over Bahrain. 2. Since this permission was accorded, however, the Sheikh of Bahrain has drawn the a ftp ntion of His Majesty’s Government to certain cases in which aircraft belonging to the Royal Dutch Air Line bearing registration marks other than those mentioned above have landed at Bahrain. For instance on the 30th November, 1936 Jonkheer R. de Marees van Swinderen, G.C.V.O. etc., etc., etc. a/a K*L.M. air liner bearing the registration mark PH-ALP, was compelled, after a wireless notification, to make an emergency landing at Bahrain. Although this machine was not one of the aircraft authorised to use the Muharraq. aerodrome nevertheless, in the circumstances, the Bahrain Government, as a friendly action, permitted it to refuel and proceed on its way without delay. 3. Again, on the 12th December, 1936 another unauthorised K.L.M. aircraft, bearing the registration mark PH-AKR made an emergency landing at Bahrain through shortage of petrol, but was -permitted to proceed. 4. The landings of these unauthorised aircraft have been the subject of a formal protest by the Bahrain Government and, in view of the Air Navigation Regulations for Civil Aircraft made by His Rxcellency the Sheikh of Bahrain, (a copy of which was sent to you in my note No. S 7233/17/91 of the 23rd December, 1935,) I have the honour to suggest that the fact that this protest has been made should be brought to the notice of the Company and that steps should be taken to make certain that they understand that it is incumbent upon them to obtain a special authorisation for each individual aircraft which may require emergency landing facilities at the aerodrome at Muharraq, or permission to fly over Bahrain. I have the honour to be with the highest consideration, Sir, Your obedient Servant, (For the Secretary of State) (Sd.) I.—Heads of Agreement between His Majesty’s Government in the United Kingdom and His Excellency Sheikh Hamad bin ’Isa A1 Khalifah, C.S.I., Ruler of Bahrein.' :;: ' 1. The Sheikh agrees to grant to His Majesty’s Government exclusive rights to establish and maintain as his agents and subject to the provisions of this Agreement and of. the Air Navigation Regulations for Civil Aircraft issued by him, an aerodrome or aerodromes and ancillary services within the Sheikh’s territory, and to charge fees in respect of the use of the aerodrome or aerodromes and such ancillary services. 2. The Shaikh agrees that sole discretion as to the appointment of agents (a) to manage and (b) to maintain the aerodrome or aerodromes on their behalf shall be vested in His Majesty’s Government during the period of this Agreement. Such agents shall exercise supervision, in respect of such aerodrome or aerodromes, necessary for the carrying out of the Air Navigation Regulations, with the exception of air sanitary formalities which will be exercised by the Quarantine Medical Officer, and of the passport and customs regulations, which will be exercised by the Passport and Customs officials respectively of the Sheikh. 3. Aircraft authorised by the Sheikh under the Air Navigation Regulations to fly in his territory shall be permitted to use the aerodrome or aerodromes subject to the conditions to this Agreement. 4. His Majesty’s Government shall not grant without the consent of the Sheikh the use of the aerodrome or aerodromes to foreign aircraft. 5. All transactions and correspondence, whether^ by British or foreign companies or pilots, shall be conducted through the British Political Authorities. 6. The use of the aerodrome (or aerodromes) and facilities shall be subject to the conditions approved by the Sheikh set out in the Schedule attached to this Agreement, subject to such amendments as may from time to time be agreed. 7. The Sheikh agrees that His Majesty’s Government may erect, maintain and operate, either directly or through agents appointed by them, a wireless transmitting and receiving and direction-finding station for the purpose of communicating with aircraft, provided that the existing W/T service of Imperial and International Communications, Limited, is not thereby prejudiced. 8. Aircraft authorised to fly over or land in the territory of the Sheikh shall be allowed to send and receive communications by wireless to and from such station. 9. The Sheikh agrees that His Majesty’s Government directly or through their agents shall charge landing and housing fees and other charges specified in Schedule II to this Agreement as amended from time to time, and that in recognition of His Majesty’s Government’s expenditure on the aerodrome and of the consideration paid to the Sheikh under clause 16 below, His Majesty’s Government shall for the period of this Agreement retain such fees and charges. 10. His Majesty’s Government shall fix and post up in a prominent place at the aerodrome a scale of charges for attendance and facilities for aircraft and personnel using the aerodrome. 11. His Majesty’s Government shall have the sole right to supply either directly or through their agents fuel and lubricants to users of the aerodrome at rates which shall be posted up in a prominent place on the aerodrome. * These Heads of Agre ement between the Sheikh of Bahrein and His Majesty’s Government are confidential and are not for publication . 2901 75 7.34 A2 12 The Sheikh agrees to grant to His Majesty’s Government or their appointed agents the right to send from and receive at any W/T station established and operated under this Agreement wireless communications relating to aircraft and to levy and retain charges in respect of such communications. 13. The Sheikh agrees that His Majesty’s Government or their appointed agents may levy and retain charges in respect of meteorological reports and messages specially obtained or sent by them in relation to airmaft. 14. The Sheikh agrees that His Majesty’s Government may at their option arrange with users of the aerodrome for the payment by such users to them of a consolidated sum in respect of all charges, including landing and housing fees, arising in connection with their user of the said aerodrome. 15. The Sheikh agrees to exempt from customs or other duties petrol and oil imported by His Majesty’s Government or their appointed agents for the purpose of refuelling aircraft, aircraft and spare parts therefor, aero engines and parts therefor, wireless and D/F apparatus for the wireless and direction-finding station and spare parts therefor. 16. His Majesty’s Government shall pay to the Sheikh in respect of the lease of the aerodrome, and for the privileges enumerated above, an annual inclusive rental of £500 for a period of four years, and a sum representing the customs duty on petrol and oil retailed in Bahrein by His Majesty’s Government or their agents for the refuelling of aircraft other than those of Imperial Airways, Limited. 17. This Agreement shall be renewable, at the option of His Majesty’s Government with the concurrence of the Sheikh, at the conclusion of four years from the date of signature, subject to such amendments as may be thought to be desirable by His Majesty’s Government and the Sheikh. Made at Bahrein, this 6th day of June 1934. II.—Conditions laid down with the approval of the Sheikh of Bahrein to govern the use of the Aerodrome at Muharraq. 1. Liability will not be accepted by the Sheikh or by His Majesty’s Government, their servants or agents, for loss or damage by accident, fire, flood, tempest, explosion or any other cause to aircraft, or for loss or damage from whatever cause arising to goods, mails or other articles or for loss or injury from whatever cause arising to passengers or other persons (including pilots, engineers or other personnel of aircraft) landing at, departing from, or accommodated in or at the Muharraq aerodrome (even if such loss, damage or injury is caused by or arises from negligence on the part of such servants or agents). 2. The fees payable in respect of landings and accommodation are as specified in the First Schedule hereto. Landing fees will be assessed according to the maximum permissible weight authorised by the certificate of airworthiness of the aircraft. 3. Landing fees do not include attendance or other services. (For these, see Second Schedule attached below.) 4. Supplies of fuel and lubricant for aircraft at the aerodrome must be obtained from the agents appointed to manage the aerodrome at the current rates posted up at the aerodrome. 5. The foregoing fees and charges will be payable on demand. 6. Other services which may be required will be a matter for direct arrangement with the aerodrome authorities.4 ([[{) The personnel of the aircraft shall be of the prescribed number and description and shall be provided with the prescribed certificates of competency and licences. (iv) There shall be carried in the aircraft the prescribed documents and journey log book kept up to date in the prescribed form and manner. In addition, if the aircraft carries passengers, there shall be carried a list of their names, and if it carries freight, bills of lading and manifest in respect thereof. _ (v) In this regulation “ prescribed ” means prescribed by the law of the State on whose register the aircraft is entered. 4. The aircraft shall not use as a place of landing or departure any place other than the aerodrome at Muharraq. The published conditions governing the use of the aerodrome shall be observed. 5. The aircraft and the persons on board shall conform to such orders as may be^ lawfully given by any authorised person. G. Personnel of the aircraft required to be provided with licences shall on demand produce their licences for the inspection of any authorised person. The person in charge of the aircraft shall on demand by an authorised person produce any prescribed certificate, licence or log book relating to the aircraft and, if it carries passengers or freight, the list of names and the bills of lading and manifest respectively. 7. Any authorised person shall have the right of access at all reasonable times to any aircraft for the purpose of carrying out his powers and duties under these regulations. 8. The aircraft shall comply with the rules as to lights and signals and rules for air traffic prescribed in Annex D of the Convention for the Regulation of Aerial Navigation, dated the 13th October 1919. 9. The aircraft shall comply in customs matters with the provisions of Annex H of the aforesaid Convention. 10. The aircraft and persons on board shall immediately on arrival from abroad and prior to departure for abroad submit to the sanitary formalities prescribed by the Public Health Administration. 11. The time of the intended arrival from abroad and of departure for abroad from Muharraq Aerodrome shall be notified beforehand to the Customs, Public Health and Police Administrations. 12. Persons on board aircraft shall be in possession of valid national passports to be produced on demand to any authorised person. Through passengers not breaking journey will not require transit visas. Passengers breaking journey or leaving the aerodrome will need visas for the State. 13. Subject to the provisions of these regulations the laws and regulations for the time being in force in Bahrein concerning the entry into and departure from Bahrein of persons by sea and land, and concerning the importation into and the exportation from Bahrein of goods by sea or land shall apply equally and respectively to the entry and departure of persons, and the importation and exportation of goods, by air. 14. (i) If an aircraft flies in contravention of or fails to comply with these regulations or any provision thereof, or if in or in respect of the aircraft any act is committed which is or is deemed to be a contravention of these regulations or any provision thereof the pilot of the aircraft shall be deemed to have contravened these regulations. # .... (ii) If any person obstructs or impedes any authorised person in the exercise of his powers and duties under these regulations, such first-mentioned person shall be deemed to have acted in contravention of these regulations. (iii) If any person contravenes or fails to comply with these regulations or any provision thereof he shall be dealt with according to law. 15. The expression ‘‘authorised person” means any person authorised by His Excellency the Sheikh of Bahrein. P.Z.2370/36 Department. 2 ^ ^luli KCt #/-4 *V(/( lu 4 ^ 7X foij ^ At the time of the opening of the British Civil Air Boute along the Arab Coast of the Persian Gulf, enquiries were received from the French and Dutch Governments asking whether similar facilities would be granted to their aircraft^ The matter was discussed at an interdepartmental meeting in X July 1932, and after considerable discussion it was decided that it would be politically undesirable to refuse such requests. For the moment, however, the grant of facilities was confined to flights over Bahrein and Gwadur and the use of the Muharraq and Gwadur aerodromes. In regard to the intermediate stage it was felt that it was undesirable to grant any facilities until more experience had been gained. In reporting the results of the meeting to the Government of India the following passage is relevant; u as regards Shsagah, we are, of course, fully alive to the undesirability of admitting foreigners to the Trucial area, though ultimately the same facilities as are enjoyed by Imperial Airways may have to be accorded them. For the moment, therefore, we propose to inform the Dutch that until the question has been more thoroughly examined and the new route tested by practical experience it is impossible to say what facilities, if any, can be afforded to their aircraft. n (P.Z.4521/32). Moes, Inspector General of the K.L.1J. > passed through Bushire. I had him up for lunch and we had an informal conversation on this subject. He is a very pleasant individual as axe most of the Dutchmen I have met. 3 # jn the first place Mr. Moes said that there was no particular urgency for his Company to move from the Persian to the Arab side, and that they might never 4o so as the Persian side, from the flying point of view, suited them somewhat better. Their present arrangements with the Iranian Government were roughly on the basis of a 3-monthly notice and for the moment things were going fairly smoothly. There was, however, no guarantee that at some time in the future the Iranian authorities might not either refuse them permission to continue flying, or make considerable difficulties for them. The Bushire aerodrome, too, was no means satisfactory. In these circumstances the K.L.1I. would like a second string to their bow in the shape of permission to fly down the Arab Coast. 4 . On the subject of the Trucial Coast Mr. Moes stated categorically (what I rather envisaged in paragraph 3 (2) of / J.G.kfalton Esquire,GB.,MG., The India Office, London.-2 of my Express Letter quoted above} that the hop from Bahrain to Gwadur was far too long for their machines and that the K.L.M. would definitely want permission to use the Sharjah and , _ aerodrome regularly^/to fly across the Ras Musandum peninsula. He added that as a matter of fact they already flew over the tip of the peninsula, (a glance at the map will show that this is the direct route between Jask, where they have one of their aerodromes, and Bushire), and suggested that apart from other considerations it might be as well to regularise the position. He said that if they gave up the Bushire aerodrome they might still retain the one at Jask (though of course this depended upon the Iranian Government) and fly from Bagdad to Bahrain and thence to Jask instead of to Gwadur. But even in this case they would want landing facilities at Sharjah. He said that while he quite understood when first we opened the Arab Air Route we were unable to give permission for his Company to land at Sharjah, he hoped now that the Route had been in operation for some years there would be no difficulty about this. He himself had flown in Imperial Airways up and down the Arab Route on various occasions and understood that the Shaikhs welcomed the presence of aircraft and that there was no likelihood of trouble arising. 5. with regard to the Trucial Coast I stated that naturally I could not commit myself as to whether His Majesty’s Government would give the necessary permission, though doubtless his Company would take the matter up through their Legation in London. P.Z. 4121/34 Air Navigation Regulations for Civil Aircraft for the Territory of Bahrein, and Conditions governing the use of the Aerodrome at Muharraq approved by His Excellency Sheikh Hamad bin Tsa A1 Khalifah, C.S.I., Ruler of Bahrein. I.—Air Navigation Regulations for Civil Aircraft. 1; Aircraft shall not fly over or land in the territory of Bahrein except under a special authorisation issued by His Excellency the Sheikh. 2. Aircraft so authorised, when flying over or landing in the territory of Bahrein, shall comply wdth the following general regulations in addition to such other supplementary conditions as may be specified in the authorisation. g- (i) The aircraft shall be registered and bear the prescribed nationality and registration marks painted on the aircraft in the prescribed manner. (ii) The aircraft shall be certified as airworthy in the prescribed manner, and any terms or conditions on or subject to which the certificate of airworthiness was granted shall be duly complied with. (iii) 1 he personnel of the aircraft shall be of the prescribed number and description and shall be provided with the prescribed certificates of competency and licences. (iv) There shall be carried in the aircraft the prescribed documents and journev log book kept up to date in the prescribed form and manner. In addition, if the aircraft carries passengers, there shall be carried a list of their names and, if it carries freight, bills of lading and manifest in respect thereof. (v) In this regulation “prescribed” means prescribed by the law of the State on whose register the aircraft is entered. 4. The aircraft shall not use as a place of landing or departure any place other than the aerodrome at Muharraq. The published conditions governing the use of the aerodrome shall be observed. 5. The aircraft and the persons on board shall conform to such orders as may be lawfully given by any authorised person. 6. Personnel of the aircraft required to be provided with licences shall on demand produce their licences for the inspection of any authorised person. The person in charge of the aircraft shall on demand by an authorised person produce any prescribed certificate, licence or log book relating to the aircraft and, if it carries passengers or freight, the list of names and the bills of lading and manifest respectively. 7. Any authorised person shall have the right of access at all reasonable times to any aircraft for the purpose of carrying out his powers and duties under these regulations. 8. The aircraft shall comply with the rules as to lights and signals and rules for air traffic prescribed in Annex D of the Convention for the Regulation of Aerial Navigation, dated 13th October 1919. 9. The aircraft shall comply in customs matters with the provisions of Annex H of the aforesaid Convention. 10. The aircraft and persons on board shall immediately on arrival from abroad and prior to departure for abroad submit to the sanitary formalities prescribed by the Public Health Administration. 11. The time of the intended arrival from abroad at, and of departure for abroad from Muharraq Aerodrome shall be notified beforehand to the Customs, Public Health and Police Administrations. 12. Persons on board aircraft shall be in possession of valid national passports to be produced on demand to any authorised person. Through passengers not breaking journey will not require transit visas. Passengers breaking journey or leaving the aerodrome will need visas for the State. 13. Subject to the provisions of these regulations, the laws and regulations for the time being in force in Bahrein concerning the entry into and departure from Bahreinof persons by sea and land and concerning the importation into and the exportation from Bahrein of goods by sea or land shall apply equally and respectively to the entry and departure of persons, and the importation and exportation of goods, by air. 14. -—(i) If an aircraft flies in contravention of or fails to comply with these regulations or any provision thereof or if in or in respect of the aircraft any act is committed which is or is deemed to be a contravention of these regulations or any provision thereof, the pilot of the aircraft shall be deemed to have contravened these regulations. (ii) If any person obstructs or impedes any authorised person in the exercise of his powers and duties under these regulations, such first-mentioned person shall be deemed to have acted in contravention of these regulations. (iii) If any person contravenes or fails to comply with these regulations or any provision thereof, he shall be dealt with according to law. 15. The expression “ authorised person ” means any person authorised by His Excellency the Sheikh of Bahrein. Dated the 6th June 1934 (Safar 1353). II.—Conditions governing the use of the Aerodrome at Muharraq. L Liability will not be accepted by the Sheikh or by His Majesty’s Government, their servants or agents for loss or damage by accident, fire, flood, tempest, explosion oi any other cause to aircraft, or for loss or damage from whatever cause arising to goods, mails, or other articles, or for loss or injury from whatever cause arising to passengers or other persons (including pilots, engineers or other personnel of aircraft! landing at, departing from or accommodated in or at the Muharraq aerodrome (even if such loss, damage or injury is caused by or arises from negligence on the part of such servants or agents). 2. The fees payable in respect of landings and accommodation are as specified in the First Schedule hereto. Landing fees will be assessed according to the maximum permissible weight authorised by the certificate of airworthiness of the aircraft. 3. Landing fees do not include attendance or other services. (For these see Second Schedule below.) V 4. Supplies of fuel and lubricant for aircraft at the aerodrome must be obtained from the agents appointed to manage the aerodrome at the current rates posted up at the aerodrome. 5. The foregoing fees and charges will be payable on demand. 6. Other services which may be required will be a matter for direct arrangement with the aerodrome authorities.APPENDIX. Form of Special Authorisation for Aircraft to land in Muharraq and fly over Bahrein. 1. The Sheikh of Bahrein hereby authorises the flight within the limits of Bahrein of the following aircraft of nationality :— Registered owner. Type of aircraft. Registration mark. 2. This authorisation is limited to the period from to inclusive and is granted subject to the following conditions :— (i) The aircraft, their crews and passengers shall be liable to all the legal obligations which arise from general legislation, from customs and excise legislation, and import and export regulations and any regulations which may be laid down for public safety as well as the air navigation regulations attached hereto. (ii) The aircraft shall not use as a place of landing or departure within Bahrein any place other than the aerodrome at Muharraq and the published conditions governing the use of the said aerodrome shall be observed. (iii) This authorisation or a certified true copy of it shall be carried in the aircraft and be produced on demand for the inspection of any authorised person.—— rcaa tatt. -i (E 4667/17/91) d^- h-c. ^ FOREIGN OFFICE, S.W.l. 10th September, 1935. Dear Clauson, Before he went to Geneva Sterndale-Bennett asked me to write in confirmation of what he said to you on the telephone the other day about the question of communicating the Bahrain Air Navigation Regulations to the Dutch Minister. 2. As you know, when we first came to consider your letter P.3.5051/35 of the 29th July to Rendel, Sterndale- Bennett thought that we should be able to fall in with your views and refrain from sending the Bahrain regulations to the Minister unless he specifically asked for them. However, when he came to go into the matter more deeply and read the earlier correspondence on the subject, he came to the conclusion that it really was not possible for us to attempt to withhold them in view of the explicit promise given in our note of November 1933. If on reconsideration of the matter you still von cannot accree to the regulations being sentto the Minister, we can only suggest that you should take the matter up with us officially. Our own feeling is that as both His Majesty’s Government and the Sheikh are already committed to granting the Dutch permission to fly over Bahrain any time that they may make an application to do so, it is unlikely that the mere communication of the regulations would lead them to decide to transfer their air route to the southern shore of the Gulf. 4. I had intended to send you over herewith drafts of the note to the Duoch Minister and of a despatch to the Embassy in Paris instructing them to communicate the Muscat regulations to the French and to tell them to made the necessary application to land at Gwadur. However, I now find that there is no print of the Bahrain regulations available for sending to the Minister; a print was made and copies sent to us in your printed letter P.Z.4121/34 of the 3rd August 1934, but it contained a misprint in Part II. I see that in his letter to Bertram P.Z.6845/34 of 7th November 1934 Laithwaite saidsaid xhat it was proposed to correct this error wnen the Muscat agreement was through, hut we do not appear to have received any copies of an amended print of the Bahrain regulations. 5. Perhaps you will let Malcolm know whether there is likely to he a corrected print available soon; if not, and it is decided to send Monsieur van Swinderen the regulations, we shall presumably have to have them typed out here. Alternatively, if the print was likely to he ready soon, we could forward the Muscat regulations and add that the Bahrain ones nad also been issued and would he communicated to him as soon as available in print (there is, of course, no question of communicating the Bahrain regulations to the French). In any case, it will apparently he necessary to leave sub-section (c) of Schedule II blank, as in the Muscat print; but Bertram explained in his letter to Rendel No. S.32956 of the 23rd July that there is no reason why this should hold up matters. 6. Walton, Esq., C.B., M.CMinister the civil air navigation regulations for Bahrein , as well as those for Muscat, You will remember that the question of communicating the Bahrein regulations to M. van Swinderen formed the subject of semi-official correspondence earlier in the year (ending with Laithwaite*s letter to * Johnstone, P,Z, 1258/35 of 26th February), as a result of which it was decided that there was no necessity at present to take any initiative in the matter. On the other hand when informing the Minister in our official note E 6461/11/91 of 13th November, 1933, that the Sultan of Bahrein had given his consent in principle to the regular use of Bahrein by Dutch aircraft, we did promise to communicate the technical and financial conditions on which foreign aviation companies might use Bahrein territory as soon as they were received from the Sheikh, It is true that the Dutch/Dutch Minister has not raised the matter since then, hut there seems to he no douht that if the K.L.M. should at any time, decide to make regular use of Bahrein (i.e. to transfer their route from the Persian to the Arabian side of the Gulf), both His Majesty’s Government and the Sheikh of Bahrein are committed to granting the required permission. We should then in any case, have to communicate the relevant regulations to the Dutch Government, and as the regulations will have been in existence for a long time (they are a year old already) they might well consider that we had failed to implement the undertaking given to M. van Swinderen in our note of November, 1933, and feel that they had not been treated very courteously in the matter. Subject to your and Bertram’s views I suggest that the present occasion of our communicating the Muscat regulations provides a convenient opportunity for sending the Dutch Minister the Bahrein regulations as well. 4. Another point which I think requires consideration before any of the air navigation regulations are communicated to foreign Governments is that of the second schedule of charges which it was decided should be attached to the various air navigation regulations to cover the fees for attendance and certain other services which would be performed by the staff of Imperial Airways, Limited, in their capacity of agents of His Majesty^ Government. I take it, too, that His Majesty^ Government will require to approve the fees; that the Air Ministry would be kept at least generally in touch with any negotiations of a bargaining nature Imperial Airways may have on the subject with foreign aviation companies, and that they (the Air Ministry) would keep us informed as necessary. My dear Warner, Would you kindly refer to my letter of 22nd August, No.P.Z.5180/33, to Bertram of the Air Ministry on the subject of the charges to be made by Imperial Airways in respect of Agency Services at the Arab Aerodromes in the Persian Gulf and Bertram’s reply of 27th September, ltfo.248985/33/D.D.C.A., enclosing a letter from Imperial Airways and enquiring whether it would not be possible in the circumstances discussed to postpone for the present a declaration of charges for public transport aircraft at the Arabian Coast aerodromes, of which a copy was sent by us to the Foreign Office at the time. I fear that owing to pressure of more urgent work we have so far taken no action on Bertram’s letter. I should now be grateful for your observations on the 1 point he raises. We are, of course, anxious, so far as is reasonably possible to assist Imperial Airways in matters such as the present, and we fully recognise that they might be in a better position to bargain with the Dutch if they were able to hold over the head of the latter the threat of retaliation at the Civil Aerodromes in the Persian Gulf. On the other hand, the whole object, I think, of the policy we have adopted in dealing with the Civil Aerodromes on the Arab littoral has been to avoid precisely the type of difficulty which might arise in the event of Imperial Airways using the threat of increased charges at e.g. Bahrein or Koweit as a bargaining lever with foreign commercial canpanies in order to secure better terms for themselves in sane other section of their route to Australia. We aimed in these circumstances at securing/ C.F.A.Wahner, Esq.,— i wmt - securing that the local ruler would prescribe the terms on which foreign aircraft might use the aerodromes in his State and that Imperial Airways in charging foreign planes at a fixed rate for services rendered, would do so within the terns of the Sheikh's regulations and would recover charges from such planes at rates fixed by him and under his authority. I am rather inclined to think in these circumstances, subject to the views of the Foreign Office, that despite the disadvantage at which this may to some extent place Imperial Airways, it will be necessary to ask them to let us have at this stage (or at any rate in advance of any opening of the route to the Dutch or other foreign commercial aircraft) the charges they propose to make for public transport aircraft at the Arabian Coast Aerodromes. I should, however, be grateful for your observations in the light of which we might if necessary discuss the matter with Bertram, to whom and to McClaughry, I am sending a copy of this letter. (Sgd.) After considerable discussion it was decided that it would be impossible to refuse such requests, but that we should confine the grant of facilities, at any rate at the present stage, to Bahrein and Gwadur; that with regard to the intermediate stage we should state that numerous difficulties haa still to be overcome ana that it woula not be possible to state what facilities, if |any, coula be afforded until the question had been, more thoroughly examined ana the new route put to the test of practical experience (in other words, that we would not agree to trie use of our station at Shargah); and that in general we should require a formal undertaking from the foreign Governments concerned that every effort would be made by their civil aircrait to keep exactly to an agreed route and to comply strictly with any advice they might receive from British officials in the Persian Gulf area. 2* The French have now expressed appreciation of our attitude, but havejintMated that they propose to continue to fly along the Persian side of the Gulf, although they had “been unable to secure the renewal of the Persian Government's pemission for any definite period and were thus obliged to apply for their 'sanction for each separate flight.' Sir, In your notes Nos.889 of the 17th June and 957 of the 5th July you were so good as to put forward certain proposals for the improvement of civil aviation facilities on the Eastern air route, and to enquire as to the facilities which might eventually be made available for Netherlands flying services on the Arabian Coast of the Persian Gulf. 2. In reply, I have the honour to inform you that His Majesty’s Government in the United Kingdom fully appreciate the desirability of co-operation between those Governments which are interested in the development of civil aviation, and, more particularly, in the operation of a civil air route to India and the Ear East. Any proposals having as their object the improvement of conditions on this route, by means of the joint endeavours of the Governments primarily concerned, will always receive their sympathetic consideration. 3. His Majesty’s Government have thus received and considered with the greatest sympathy the present suggestion of the Netherlands Government for joint representations to the Governments of certain oriental countries situated on the Eastern air route, such as Iraq and Persia, involving a proposal that the cost of satisfactory ground equipment at the necessary aerodromes might be borne, in whole or in part, by the Governments of the Netherlands, of France, and of the United Kingdom. 4. They agree that representations on these lines might well, in certain circumstances, have a useful effect, especially/ Jonlcheer H.de Marees van Swinderen, G.C.V.O. , etc. , etc. , etc.Iespecially if all other methods of persuading a Government to provide the necessary facilities were to prove unavailing. In practice, however, His Majesty’s Government are not convinced that circumstances render it desirable to approach either the Persian Government or the Iraqi Government on these lines for the present. 5. So far as Persia is concerned, the existing facilities at Bushire and Jask do not appear to be inadequate. In any case, however, it would not be practicable for His Majesty’s Government to join in the proposed representations to the Persian Government at present, in view of the decision, referred to in your note of July 5th, that Imperial Airways machines shall follow a route along the Arabian Coast of the Persian Gulf after October 1st next, the date on which their present permit fran the Persian Government expires. His Majesty’s Government have therefore no immediate interest in the upkeep of suitable facilities for a commercial air service in Persian aerodromes. 6 . As regards Iraq, very considerable facilities for civil air services already exist, and where, as at Basra, such facilities are not yet entirely satisfactory, the Iraqi Government, who have shown themselves actively interested in civil aviation, are themselves engaged in an endeavour to improve them. 7. In brief, therefore, the views of His Majesty’s Government are that where, as in Persia, reasonably adequate facilities for a civil air service are already provided, or where, as in Iraq, the territorial government is itself actively engaged in an attempt to improve the existing facilities, it is unnecessary for the governments of the operating companies to institute joint representations/representations in the sense proposed hy the Netherlands Government. At the same time, if all other methods failed, His Majesty’s Government might in principle he prepared to join in such representations in any cases where they should appear essential at a later stage. S. As regards the intention to establish an air route along the Arabian coast of the Persian Gulf on October 1st next, I have the honour to explain that the necessary arrangements are not yet complete. It is therefore difficult to state what facilities it will eventually be possible to offer to the aircraft of the Royal Dutch Air Transport Company (K.L.M.). I have little doubt that the Governments of Muscat and Bahrein would be willing, if approached, to grant the Company’s aircraft facilities at Gwadur and Bahrein similar to those which will be enjoyed by Imperial Airways Limited, and I shall be happy to forward by telegraph to these Governments an official application on behalf of the Netherlands Government for the necessary permission, on learning that you desire me to do so. In view, however, of the exceptional local conditions existing in this area and of the special treaty relations existing between these Arab States and His Majesty’s Government, I should be glad to receive at the same time a formal assurance that in the event of the necessary permission being granted by the Governments of Muscat and Bahrein respectively, the Dutch air service would make every effort to keep exactly to an agreed route, and would comply strictly with any advice \ which they might receive from the British officials in the Persian Gulf area, who alone are in a position to foresee local difficulties, and, by guarding against them, to secure the maximum degree of smooth working for the air 9./ID 9. With regard to the intermediate stage between Bahrein and Gwadur, numerous difficulties have yet to be overcome, and it will not be possible to state what facilities, if any, can be afforded to the Royal Butch service until the question has been more thoroughly examined and the new route put to the test of practical experience. titleInfo.title: Coll 5/18 ‘Air Route to India (Arab Coast): Use of landing grounds by foreign aircraft’

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the rear to the front of the file.

Foliation: the foliation sequence commences at the inside front cover with 1, and terminates at the last folio with 545; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. A previous foliation sequence, which is present between ff 2-544 is also circled, but has been superseded and therefore crossed out.

mods.abstract: The file contains correspondence, and related India Office notes, regarding the Arabian Coast air route linking Europe and Asia. In particular, it is concerned with Britain's policy over restricting access to this route to non-British aircraft. It contains applications from the Governments of France, Italy, and the Netherlands for permission for their companies to access this route. These companies being: Air France, Ala Littoria, and Koninklijke Luchtvaart Maatschappij (KLM) respectively. The focus of these applications is on obtaining access to landing grounds at Gwadur, Kuwait, Bahrain (Muharraq), Sharjah, and Yas Island. The file contains a record of the British response to these applications, which is largely correspondence between officials over the extent that they can legitimately exclude these companies from the region; there is particular concern over keeping Sharjah aerodrome an exclusively British preserve.As a result of a policy decision made by the British Government to allow Air France and KLM access to Muharraq and Gwadur (for refuelling and in cases of emergency), the file includes periodic applications from these companies to the Shaikh of Bahrain and the Sultan of Muscat for authorisation to use these aerodromes.The correspondence dating from the Second World War (1939-1945) largely relates to a reversal of British policy – due to wartime difficulties – which allowed KLM to run regular air services via Bahrain and Sharjah for the duration of the war. It also contains discussion related to an attempt to secure a wartime agreement to facilitate the utilisation of KLM aircraft for war purposes by the British.The correspondence with the Government of France and with Air France is in French, as is a small proportion of the correspondence with the Government of the Netherlands. Overall, the French language content forms only a small proportion of the material within the file.The main correspondents are as follows: the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, the Political Agent at Bahrain, and the Political Agent and Consul at Muscat. There is also correspondence with officials of the following British Government departments: the Air Ministry, the Foreign Office, the India Office, and the Foreign and Political Department of the Government of India (External Affairs Department from 1937). Correspondence is frequently forwarded to the Under-Secretary of State for India by the Under-Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs.The file includes a divider which gives a list of correspondence references contained in the file by year. This is placed at the back of the correspondence.
